label.intro:
Treatments enable us to do comparisons that determine cause and effect.


Treatments, or “interventions”, allow for the comparison of different levels or conditions to investigate how they impact the outcome variable, enabling the examination of cause and effect relationships.


The introduction of a treatment means that we are now dealing with an experiment: experiments are surveys with a treatment effect. What sets apart an experiment from a survey is the existence of a treatment effect. You might have an experiment that “looks like” a traditional survey, or a survey that “looks like” a traditional experiment. For example, say you take soil samples from a field and analyse them in a lab - if there is no treatment, then this is just a survey.
